Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A phylogenetic study of speciation in whirligig beetles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Whirligig beetles are a family of aquatic beetles containing approximately 1,000 species. All whirligig beetles live in very similar ways, yet exhibit a great morphological diversity. What can explain the diversity of species in this family of beetles, who all behave and live in similar ways? This research attempts to establish if selection on reproductive traits has been a major factor in the evolution of this group leading to its diversity of species. The investigation will look at numerous reproductively selected features in these beetles, then using a phylogenetic tree, compare related groups to see if branches of the tree with more species, also show a larger number of selected traits. One of the traits to be studied is sperm shape. Whirligig beetle sperm show a diversity of forms and the reconstructed evolution of sperm in this group will be compared to the rate of speciation.
Selection on reproductive traits has long been promoted as a powerful force for creating new species. However, few studies supporting this idea have looked at large evolutionary scales. The study of sperm within this group can be used to test previously established hypotheses about sperm and female reproductive tract co-evolution, as well as make known the diversity of whirligig beetle sperm, including several types of conjugation and a variety of sizes. This project will train graduate student in evolutionary biology and this student will mentor several undergraduate students in systematics and arthropod curation. Identified specimens will be accessioned at UNM and included in a publicly accessible database enhancing infrastructure for research and education.

The primary objectives of the the Doctoral Dissertation Improvemant grant awarded to Grey Gustafson have been completed. The grant was used to fund two field expeditions. The first to Madagascar and the second to Australia. Below the results from the two expeditions is provided.

1) Madagascar Expedition November 2014

The primary objective of this expedition was to sample sperm from the Malagasy striped whirligig beetle (Heterogyrus milloti). 

The Co-PIs traveled to Madagascar with the goal of sampling sperm from all the genera of whirligig beetles present on the island. They were able to successfully locate the Malagasy striped whirligig beetle in Ranomafana National Park. There they obsevered never before documented behavior from the beetle. The aquatic beetle was found to be able to jump, and quite adeptly, when placed on land. They also documented that the beetles orient themselves down stream before proceeding to jump, again when removed from the puddles where the beetles were found swimming. Sperm was harvested from beetles taken back to camp later.

The Co-PIs were able to locate all the genera of whirligig beetles known to occur on the island and gather sperm specimens from them.

Upon return to the lab at the University of New Mexico, the sperm slides have been prepared and examined by the Co-PIs. We are happy to report that we successfully obtained sperm from all genera on Madagascar, including that of the Malagasy striped whirligig. As suspected the beetles have exceptionally small sperm (see attached image). Further measurements must be taken in order to confirm the exact size range of the sperm and if it indeed represents the small sperm currently known for any species of beetle. 

Additional examination of specimens collected of the Malagasy striped whirligig revealed the mechanism the beetles use for jumping. The hind leg has a ridge that appears to hook and hold the leg in order to build up force, that when the leg is released, allow the beetles to jump. An image of this ridge is provided above. 

Another finding of note was the collection of a new species of whirligig beetle of the genus Gyrinus. 

2) Australia Expedition January 2015

The primary objective of this expedition was to sample sperm from the largely Australian whirligig beetle genus, Macrogyrus. 

The Co-PIs traveled to Australia with the goal of sampling sperm from several Macrogyrus species. Once there they were able to locate and sample sperm from four different species. One of the species was M. striolatus which is not commonly collected, and is one of the largest Macrogyrus species known. The PIs were also able to sample sperm from the whirligig beetle genus Aulonogyrus. This was of interest as this genus also has species of Madagascar, which were sampled during the Madagascar expedition. 

Upon returning back to the lab, sperm slides where stained, prepared, and examined. We were successful in collecting sperm from both Macrogyrus and from Aulonogyrus. The sperm of Macrogyrus has a rod, the spermatostyle, similar to that of the genus Dineutus, known from North America. However the sperm are predominantly attached to one end of the rod (unlike in Dineutus where they attach fairly evenly all along the rod). Attached is an image of the sperm of Macrogyrus.
